qas.question: Whom found Wente-style condenser microphones helpful?
How were Wente-Style condenser microphones helpful?
When was a pre-emphasis most useful?
On which recording types were pre-emphasis used most in the 1920s?
In which Era was this finding most significant?

context: West in 1930 and later <a0_0>P. G. A. H. Voigt<a0_0/> (1940) showed that the early Wente-style condenser microphones contributed to a 4 to 6 dB midrange brilliance or <a1_0>pre-emphasis in the recording<a1_0/> chain. This meant that the electrical recording characteristics of Western Electric licensees such as Columbia Records and Victor Talking Machine Company in the <a4_0>1925 era<a4_0/> had a higher amplitude in the midrange region. Brilliance such as this compensated for dullness in many early magnetic pickups having drooping midrange and treble response. As a result, this practice was the empirical beginning of using pre-emphasis <a2_0>above 1,000 Hz<a2_0/> in <a3_0>78 rpm and 33 1⁄3 rpm<a3_0/> records.
